results.abstract: Senate unanimously agrees to give Pres Clinton authority to temporarily waive most remaining economic sanctions on India and Pakistan; measure passes without dissent as amendment to agriculture appropriations bill; backers say it will give US greater flexibility in dealing with spread of nuclear arms in South Asia (M)

headline.main: Senate Votes to Lift Most Remaining India-Pakistan Penalties

results.snippet: The Senate unanimously agreed today to give President Clinton authority to temporarily waive most remaining economic sanctions on India and Pakistan.     The measure passed without dissent as an amendment to an agriculture appropriations bill when...
results.lead_paragraph: The Senate unanimously agreed today to give President Clinton authority to temporarily waive most remaining economic sanctions on India and Pakistan. The measure passed without dissent as an amendment to an agriculture appropriations bill when its main opponent, Senator John Glenn, Democrat of Ohio, was in Cape Canaveral, Fla., training to be an astronaut for his coming space mission.

results.abstract: Stephen Holden Critic's Notebook on New York Video Festival at Walter Reade Theater, celebrating unruly stepchild of television and cinema that has flowered into vast creative alternative culture; showings are part of Lincoln Center Festival '98; documentary and other films noted; photos; list (M)

headline.main: A Revolution Made Of Gritty Intimacy

results.snippet: Nearly 20 years ago, a catchy hit song called ''Video Killed the Radio Star'' by a group called the Buggles eerily presaged the rise of MTV and the revolution in pop-music marketing that the promotional video clip was just beginning to incite. Today,...
results.lead_paragraph: Nearly 20 years ago, a catchy hit song called ''Video Killed the Radio Star'' by a group called the Buggles eerily presaged the rise of MTV and the revolution in pop-music marketing that the promotional video clip was just beginning to incite. Today, when the mindless star-studded ''event movie'' has risen to become the economic cornerstone of the film industry, the time is more than ripe for an upstart video artist to concoct a similar fantasy that might be dubbed, ''Video Killed the Movie Star.'' In the world of the $20-million-a-picture movie-star salary, that's not going to happen any time soon. But as suggested by the work shown in the New York Video Festival, which opens today at the Walter Reade Theater, video art, that unruly stepchild of television and experimental cinema, has flowered into a vast, immensely creative alternative culture. At its most inventive, as in ''Flat Is Beautiful,'' Sadie Benning's 50-minute video evocation of preadolescent angst in a nontraditional Midwest household, experimental form and conventional narrative fuse into something extraordinarily original and touching.

results.abstract: Peter Manso profile of black novelist Gayl Jones, who took part in standoff with police that ended with suicide of husband, Bob Higgins; holds conviction that racist society doomed them to repeat their forebears' violent history united couple; photos (L)a
results.snippet: On the evening of Feb. 20, 1998, less than a week after the much-heralded publication of her first novel in more than 20 years, Gayl Jones, 48, was handcuffed and removed from her Lexington, Ky., home by the local police. Inside the two-bedroom...
results.lead_paragraph: On the evening of Feb. 20, 1998, less than a week after the much-heralded publication of her first novel in more than 20 years, Gayl Jones, 48, was handcuffed and removed from her Lexington, Ky., home by the local police. Inside the two-bedroom bungalow, her husband lay bleeding from a self-inflicted knife wound. The confrontation began just after 6 P.M., when police officers knocked on the door at 440 Locust Avenue to serve a 15-year-old warrant for the arrest of Bob Higgins, also known as Bob Jones. The man opened the door a crack, but after a brief exchange with the cops, he slammed it shut, ran to the rear of the house and reappeared, holding two knives to his throat. ''Don't come in,'' he screamed. ''I'll kill myself if you come in here.''

results.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-10 Iran Is Said to Test Medium-Range Missile Iran has successfully tested a medium-range missile, an Administration official said. The weapon, with a range of about 800 miles, could reach Israel and Saudi Arabia, altering the balance of power in the Mideast. A1

results.abstract: Alan B Shepard Jr, first American to fly in space, and later one of only 12 astronauts to walk on Moon, dies at age of 74; on May 5, 1961, Shepard, former Navy test pilot, was in cramped Mercury capsule atop seven-story Redstone rocket filled with explosive fuel; he was shot into sky on 15-minute flight that grazed fringes of space, at altitude of 115 miles, and ended in splashdown in Atlantic Ocean 302 miles from Cape Canaveral, Fla; Shepard's successs is credited with giving Pres John F Kennedy confidence, less than three weeks later, to commit nation to goal of landing man on moon within decade; photos; chronology of events in US-USSR space race in 1950's and 60's (L)

headline.main: Alan B. Shepard Jr. Is Dead at 74; First American to Travel in Space

results.snippet: Alan B. Shepard Jr., the first American to fly in space, lifting national spirits at a decisive moment of cold war anxiety, and later one of only 12 astronauts to walk on the Moon, died late Tuesday night at a hospital in Monterey, Calif. He was 74...
results.lead_paragraph: Alan B. Shepard Jr., the first American to fly in space, lifting national spirits at a decisive moment of cold war anxiety, and later one of only 12 astronauts to walk on the Moon, died late Tuesday night at a hospital in Monterey, Calif. He was 74 and lived in Houston and Pebble Beach, Calif. The family would not disclose the cause of death, saying only that it came after a long illness. But another former astronaut, Senator John Glenn of Ohio, said Mr. Shepard had been suffering from leukemia.

results.abstract: Interview with Dr Marvin Minsky, 71-year-old MIT professor and one of world's leading theorists of artificial intelligence; photo (M)

headline.main: A CONVERSATION: With Dr. Marvin Minsky; Why Isn't Artificial Intelligence More Like the Real Thing?

results.snippet: DR. MARVIN MINSKY, 71, a rumpled-looking man who wears shirts mended with masking tape, is Toshiba professor of media arts and sciences and professor of electrical engineering and computer sciences at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and...
results.lead_paragraph: DR. MARVIN MINSKY, 71, a rumpled-looking man who wears shirts mended with masking tape, is Toshiba professor of media arts and sciences and professor of electrical engineering and computer sciences at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and one of the world's leading theorists of artificial intelligence. In the late 1950's, Dr. Minsky and John McCarthy, a professor of computer science at Stanford University, founded a research program that would evolve into the MIT Artificial Intelligence Laboratory. In addition to inventing and building thinking machines, Dr. Minsky wrote the classic ''The Society of Mind,'' (Simon & Schuster, 1986) in which he tries to show how intelligence works ''by the particular way the agents in the brain have evolved to interact.'' ''The Turing Option,'' (Warner Books, 1992) a novel by Dr. Minsky and Harry Harrison, is about superintelligence in not-too-far-off 2023.
